metadata.case_name: Defendants Nos. 1 and 2 v. Balkrishna Sitaram Sontakke

facts.text: Joint Hindu family of 6 brothers carried on businesses: grocery shop, liquor shops, ration shop, motor-bus service, moneylending under Sontakke Brothers; possessed immovable and movable property.
Up to 1944, brothers lived and messed together; income from family business kept with plaintiff Balkrishna Sitaram Sontakke (eldest brother).
From April 14, 1945, parties began to appropriate proceeds of businesses separately: plaintiff ran liquor shops, defendants 1 and 2 ran motor-bus service, defendant 4 ran grocery shop.
Attempt to partition through arbitrators failed.
On June 29, 1945, five brothers filed suit No. 39 of 1945 for partition against plaintiff of all joint family properties including accounts.

Suit No. 39/1945 compromised on March 7, 1946: accounts prior to 1942 correctly maintained; arbitrators for accounts 1942 to March 31, 1946; each brother 1/6 share in cash balance; movables including stock divided equally; plaintiff gets 1/6 share in motor garage, defendants 1 and 2 to pay price.
One brother minor; court accepted compromise as beneficial, passed preliminary decree on July 25, 1947.

Plaintiff filed fresh suit No. 12/1949 on February 23, 1949, claiming share of profits/assets of motor business by defendants 1 and 2 after March 31, 1946; alleged compromise made in hurry, omitted future conduct of motor business which remained joint.
Defence: compromise after deliberation; accounts should have been to April 14, 1945 (disruption), but agreed to March 31, 1946; claim barred by res judicata.

Trial Court (Civil Judge, Thana, June 30, 1951): suit not barred by res judicata/fraud/mistake; motor business post-partition not joint but analogous to partnership post-dissolution under s.37 Partnership Act; preliminary decree for accounts from March 31, 1946 to final decree date; commissioner appointed.

High Court (Bavdekar and Dixit JJ., March 25, 1952): modified to accounts till businesses discontinued; not barred by res judicata/O.II r.2 CPC; applied s.90 Trusts Act as defendants used joint property.
Plaintiff's notice December 12, 1945: liquor licence expires end March 1946; intends to run liquor shops independently from April 1, 1946, no joint connection.
Plaintiff had Rs.13,000 cash vs brothers' Rs.3,000.
Plaintiff's application November 22, 1947 in prior suit alleging misapprehension re accounts post March 31, 1946; abandoned April 6, 1948 to pursue independent suit.

legal_issues.text: Whether the suit is barred by res judicata due to the compromise decree in suit No. 39/1945.
Whether the suit is barred by Order II rule 2(3) CPC as plaintiff relinquished claim to accounts post March 31, 1946 in prior compromise.
Whether defendants 1 and 2 liable to account for motor business profits post March 31, 1946 under s.90 Trusts Act or s.37 Partnership Act.

petitioner_arguments.text: Cause of action in both suits same (desire to separate and divide joint property); barred by res judicata and O.II r.2 CPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Res judicata; Order II rule 2 CPC

petitioner_arguments.text: Compromise after deliberation confined accounts to March 31, 1946; s.90 Trusts Act inapplicable.

respondent_arguments.text: Compromise made in hurry; omitted provision for future conduct of motor business which remained joint; right to accounts post March 31, 1946.

court_reasoning.text: Compromise confined accounts to March 31, 1946 after full consideration, not vitiated by fraud etc.; closed door to reopening beyond that date; plaintiff's notice shows intent for exclusive businesses post-date.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Parties dealt at arms length; compromise binding.

court_reasoning.text: Plaintiff abandoned right to post-1946 accounts by confining to March 31, 1946; prior suit embraced entire property; barred by res judicata as consent decree binding.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Consent decree as binding as contested decree.

court_reasoning.text: Cause of action same (separation and division); plaintiff relinquished subsequent accounts claim; barred by O.II r.2(3) CPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Omission to sue for all reliefs without leave bars later suit.

court_reasoning.text: No question of Trusts Act s.90 or Partnership Act s.37 as suit barred.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Plaintiff prevented natural course by compromise.

holdings.text: Compromise decree bars reopening accounts of motor business post March 31, 1946 by res judicata.
Suit barred by Order II rule 2(3) CPC as same cause of action, claim relinquished.
No liability to account under Trusts Act s.90 as suit not maintainable.

statutes_cited.name: Partnership Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied by trial court by analogy for post-dissolution accounting; not reached by SC

statutes_cited.name: Indian Trusts Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied by High Court for accounting by co-owners using joint property; held inapplicable by SC

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Bars suit for omitted relief on same cause of action

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside High Court decree, dismissed plaintiff's suit No. 12/1949 as barred by res judicata and Order II rule 2(3) CPC; no accounts ordered post March 31, 1946.

key_quotes.text: the only legitimate conclusion possible is that the parties had agreed to confine the taking of all accounts upto March 31,1946, and had closed the door to reopening them beyond that date.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation of compromise binding parties

key_quotes.text: a consent decree is as binding upon the parties thereto as a decree passed by invitum.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes res judicata effect of compromise decree

key_quotes.text: if a person Omits, except with the leave of the Court, to sue for all reliefs to which he is entitled, he shall not afterwards sue for any relief so omitted.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct application of O.II r.2(3) CPC
